messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
Default to use Python when not specified where applicable.
Always write python tests with the prefix `test_`.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
**Global Chat Service (GCS)**

**Overview**:  
A real-time online chat application allowing users to send text messages, images, and create group chats.

**Functional Requirements**:

1. **User Registration and Authentication**:
    - Sign up using email.
    - Forgotten password recovery.

2. **User Profile**:
    - Allow users to set profile pictures and status messages.
    - Privacy settings for who can see user details or last seen status.

3. **Contact Management**:
    - Block/unblock contacts.
    - Create, edit, and manage groups.

4. **Messaging**:
    - Send and receive real-time text messages.
    - Message read receipts (blue ticks or equivalent).
    - End-to-end encryption for security.
    - Image sharing.
    - Emojis, GIFs, and stickers support.

5. **Group Chats**:
    - Create group chats with a name and picture.
    - Add or remove participants.
    - Admin roles and permissions.

6. **Status/Story Feature**:
    - Allow users to post image statuses visible for a limited time.
    - Control who can see the status.

7. **Web Application**:
    - Web-based version accessible from browsers.

8. **Connectivity and Offline Mode**:
    - Message queuing for when the user is offline; messages are sent once connectivity is restored.
    - Display online/offline status.
```

Understand the problem, by creating a detailed step-by-step plan. Try to solve the problem in the minimal steps necessary. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. Please include a last sentence to create and run tests when implementing or writing code in that same step. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass.

function_call.name: provide_detailed_sub_task_steps_for_sub_agents
function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "1. Identify the core components of the system based on the requirements. These will include User, Chat, Message, Group, Status, and WebApp. Each of these components will have their own classes and methods. For example, the User class will have methods for registration, authentication, profile management, and contact management. The Chat class will handle messaging, including sending, receiving, and encrypting messages. The Message class will handle the content of the messages, including text, images, emojis, GIFs, and stickers. The Group class will handle group chats, including creating, managing, and administering groups. The Status class will handle the status/story feature, including posting, viewing, and managing statuses. The WebApp class will handle the web application, including displaying the user interface and handling user interactions.",
    "2. Start with the User class. Write the methods for user registration and authentication. This will include methods for signing up with an email, recovering a forgotten password, setting a profile picture and status message, and managing privacy settings. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.",
    "3. Next, write the methods for the Chat class. This will include methods for sending and receiving messages, encrypting messages, and handling read receipts. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.",
    "4. Then, write the methods for the Message class. This will include methods for handling the content of the messages, including text, images, emojis, GIFs, and stickers. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.",
    "5. After that, write the methods for the Group class. This will include methods for creating, managing, and administering groups. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.",
    "6. Then, write the methods for the Status class. This will include methods for posting, viewing, and managing statuses. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.",
    "7. Finally, write the methods for the WebApp class. This will include methods for displaying the user interface and handling user interactions. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.",
    "8. Once all the classes and methods have been written, integrate them into a complete system. This will involve writing methods for user interactions, such as logging in, sending messages, creating groups, and posting statuses. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.",
    "9. After the system has been integrated, write the entrypoint file. This will include importing the necessary classes and methods, and starting the web application. Write tests to ensure the entrypoint file works as expected.",
    "10. Finally, write the requirements.txt file. This will include all the necessary Python packages for the system. Run the system to ensure it works as expected."
  ]
}

steps: 1. Identify the core components of the system based on the requirements. These will include User, Chat, Message, Group, Status, and WebApp. Each of these components will have their own classes and methods. For example, the User class will have methods for registration, authentication, profile management, and contact management. The Chat class will handle messaging, including sending, receiving, and encrypting messages. The Message class will handle the content of the messages, including text, images, emojis, GIFs, and stickers. The Group class will handle group chats, including creating, managing, and administering groups. The Status class will handle the status/story feature, including posting, viewing, and managing statuses. The WebApp class will handle the web application, including displaying the user interface and handling user interactions.

2. Start with the User class. Write the methods for user registration and authentication. This will include methods for signing up with an email, recovering a forgotten password, setting a profile picture and status message, and managing privacy settings. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.

3. Next, write the methods for the Chat class. This will include methods for sending and receiving messages, encrypting messages, and handling read receipts. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.

4. Then, write the methods for the Message class. This will include methods for handling the content of the messages, including text, images, emojis, GIFs, and stickers. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.
5. After that, write the methods for the Group class. This will include methods for creating, managing, and administering groups. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.
6. Then, write the methods for the Status class. This will include methods for posting, viewing, and managing statuses. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.
7. Finally, write the methods for the WebApp class. This will include methods for displaying the user interface and handling user interactions. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.

8. Once all the classes and methods have been written, integrate them into a complete system. This will involve writing methods for user interactions, such as logging in, sending messages, creating groups, and posting statuses. Write tests to ensure these methods work as expected.

9. After the system has been integrated, write the entrypoint file. This will include importing the necessary classes and methods, and starting the web application. Write tests to ensure the entrypoint file works as expected.
10. Finally, write the requirements.txt file. This will include all the necessary Python packages for the system. Run the system to ensure it works as expected.
step: 1. Identify the core components of the system based on the requirements. These will include User, Chat, Message, Group, Status, and WebApp. Each of these components will have their own classes and methods. For example, the User class will have methods for registration, authentication, profile management, and contact management. The Chat class will handle messaging, including sending, receiving, and encrypting messages. The Message class will handle the content of the messages, including text, images, emojis, GIFs, and stickers. The Group class will handle group chats, including creating, managing, and administering groups. The Status class will handle the status/story feature, including posting, viewing, and managing statuses. The WebApp class will handle the web application, including displaying the user interface and handling user interactions.
